text: In this video,

we'll cover how to stream
to a Discord voice chat.
Use the clickable sections

to keep track of what step
you're on in this tutorial.
Discord is able to stream games natively,
in app on Windows,
while Mac and Linux users
can only share screens or a video.
Before your first stream,

head to your settings
to adjust a few options.
On "Voice & Video,"

you can select your input
devices for the microphone audio

and output to determine if the
audio plays through speakers,
headphones, or other devices.

For your mic, you can also
choose "Push to Talk,"
where you can only speak
when holding a specific button,
or "Voice Activity,"

which will automatically
detect when you're speaking
and share in the voice chat.
To start streaming in a voice chat,

connect to the chat and
look next to your username.
You should see two options,
one for video and one to share a screen.
Clicking "Screen" will bring you
to the source-selection page,

where you're able to choose
the windowed application
you want to share with the chat.

Select the app and then "Go
Live" to begin streaming.

Your stream preview will appear
in a small movable window.

Double-click it to bring
your preview full screen.

Or click the cog icon to
change stream resolution
and frame-rate settings.
Click "Stop Streaming" once done.

Discord can also natively
detect games running
in addition to windowed applications.
When you launch a game,

Discord will show it as a
shortcut above your name
to stream just like a normal application.
If a game or application is not detected,
go to "Game Activity" in the settings.

With the desired game
active, click "Add it."
